title: ‘Logan’ director asks public to lend support to ‘our only protection from real villains’ — the EPA
text:
— Jim Treacher (@jtLOL) March 8, 2017 
It is awfully tough to take the EPA seriously after it dumped a million gallons of toxic wastewater into the Animas River in Colorado. The EPA then let nature clean up the river and got off with barely a warning when the Obama Justice Department decided not to prosecute the EPA worker responsible for turning the river orange. 
Why is Mangold singling out the EPA for support? Because “Deepwater Horizon” actor J.D. Evermore passed along an unattributed horror story from inside the EPA. Goodbye, EPA. Please RT. pic.twitter.com/3ZkcDJnwsO 
— J.D. Evermore (@jd_evermore) March 6, 2017 
The website is being reworked to reflect the new administration’s policy? That sounds like standard operating procedure when a new administration takes over, but apparently is has thousands joining in a panic over the EPA’s future. 
Evermore was less than gentle with those who wanted to know more, such as the source of the information. 
— Kyle Cranmer (@KyleCranmer) March 6, 2017 @KyleCranmer It's from someone who still works within the department but doesn't want to be named, understandably. 
— J.D. Evermore (@jd_evermore) March 6, 2017 @jd_evermore yes, understandable. But don't really want to propagate

Whatever you do, don’t celebrate the end of the EPA as we know it. If the EPA can be stealthily shut down, i.e. no one notices or cares when it's gone, why should we waste money on it? Right. We shouldn't. https://t.co/3GqypluWKd
